description.text: Samsung Galaxy S3

Delta Printer 2020 Extrusion Slider
I got fed up with tweaking and replacing worn rollers.
Researched and Reviewed
Found sliders to be a possible solution
No fully satisfied with the designs I found
So this is what I designed.

Yes those are aeration holes! Why? Glad you asked ...
I found and printed a few slider versions from Thingiverse and the net. Each seem to hug the 2020 the side of the direction of movement do to gaps . Tighter tolerances solved this mostly but caused friction issues. Properly finishing with sanding and a light light coat of Krylon Teflon spay paint took care of the friction. Then an annoying vibration was being generated from air cushion effect.
These holes allow this air pressure to escape.
Light dab of canola oil on the inside surface when I assembled months ago and have not since.
This slider's motion is smooth and no headaches

comments.text: What infill percentage do you recommend? I see some designers recommend 100% infill on carriage components; do you recommend the same?

title: Clippable filement guide for CTC / FlashForge

description.text:
Since CTC 3D printers are essentially clones of FlashForge Creators / Makerbot Replicators, but lack the filament guide on the back, I made one myself. Doesn't require any screws, CTCs and FlashForge Creators should already have holes at just the right place.

It's clearly not as useful as some of the other filament guides on here but I've yet to see one you can just clip into the holes. It works well enough though.

Make sure to print at a high enough quality, otherwise you'll curse yourself when trying to make the clips fit.

title: 1kg plastic spool adapter for the Filament Spindle MK1 Box

description.text:
Do you have a lonely Filament Spindle MK1 Box sitting under your printer recently antiquated by the nifty new 1kg platic spools that Makerbot is now selling?  Me too ... so I set about creating an adapter that would allow the FSMK1B to use the new spools.  My situation was complicated by the fact that I had partially destroyed my FSMK1B trying to reload it with the second batch of plastic that I had bought for my printer (this was the old 5LB style).  In my adapter design I tried to address several of the things that made me want to pull my hair out about the FSMK1B original design :
1.) The whole flange assembly (the round disks holding the plastic) had to be removed from the box to add more plastic.
2.) The top flange of the spindle was almost impossible to attach.
3.) The top flange was held in using screws instead of a quick release latch.
4.) The spokes seemed a bit flimsy and were difficult to screw together.

1.) Print out two copies the adapter brackets. Face them back to back and screw them together with two 12mm socket screws. 2.) Print out the adapter strut and insert it into the socket in the brackets. Secure the adapter strut to the adapter brackets using two 12mm socket screws ( one on either side of the base). 3.) Remove the bottom flange from the FSMK1B (link to the FSMK1B instructions http://wiki.makerbot.com/spindle-mk1-assembly for terminology reference). Remove the FSMK1B struts and top flange (they are to be discarded). Attach the adapter brackets to the bottom flange using the same holes that are used to attach the turntable to the flange (not the strut holes). The turntable should also be attached to the bottom flange. 4.) Attach the bottom flange to the FSMK1B. 5.) Put the 1kg plastic filament spindle onto the adapter strut. Make sure that the side of the 1kg spindle with the recessed center is facing up. 6.) Print one copy of the adapter lid and use it to secure the spindle to the adapter. The coupling is done using a latching mechanism, so there aren't any screws necessary. Note that the adapter lid is keyed so that it will fit into the grooves on the spool ... it may be necessary to rotate the spool a little bit to get the lid to fit properly. 7.) To release the spindle squeeze the two parts of the latch on the adapter strut together and gently pull up on the spindle. NOTE : The modeling was done in Blender 2.5 and I've included the source blend file ('spindle case upgrade.blend' in the files section) to make it easier to tweak the design. The units in blend file are in inches.

title: Dual Jhead extruder & carriage, design for prusa air 2

description.text: This dual extruder use the standard Jhead mount and will perfectly fit on a prusa air 2 from Mecano (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14204). Please follow the instructions below.

This extruder works with: Mk7-like drive gear: 2x (works perfectly with qu-bd drive gear)
nut m4 x 70 : 2x
Pneufit 4mm : 4x
PTFE 4 (o) x2 (i) mm : 50 cm (2x 25mm)
Bearing 608ZZ : 2x
Jhead MK5 : 2x
Nema 17 : 2x
Spring (> 3mm inside): 3x
screw, nut, washer M3 and M4 Note on printed pieces:
You will certainly need some support material to print the extruder. The Jheads mount have adjustable 3 points leveling like prusa standard bed with springs. Nuts are blocked which make the adjustments easier. 3 points is the best compromise to mounting defaults. I used Repetier to make dual prints which work really fine, and online EEPROM write makes the gaps calibrations inprinting really really easy. A version will follow for prusa V2 extruder mount on structure. The carriage look like a monster mask without wires, which makes it even awesome ^^ (even better with pneufits)

author: UrsusTeo

title: Raw Hide Lantern Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the frame and candlelift for a raw hide lantern used by LARPers and Reenactors. Intended material is wood.
The included OpenSCAD script allows for parametrized construction of the necessary parts, just change the constants in the top part to your liking.
This instance is 25cm high and 20cm wide, and intended for the standard european tea light candle.
I will modify this thing after seein how well it works in practice, most probably with some nice handle for the candle lift. You might want to add a handle to the top part so that you can carry or hang the lamp.

Cut and drill or mill the top, bottom and candleholder parts.
Prepare the end pegs of the eight connecting rods, and glue them into the bottom part. 
Glue the lift rods into the candleholder, then insert them through the holes in the top part. 
Put top part onto connecting rods.
Cover the frame formed by the connecting rods with translucent raw hide (use stapler, glue or small nails, or sew the cover together, as in the photos).
Lift the candeholder using the longer part of the lift rods, insert candle, use!

title: Mini Pipe bender
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
as the image shows you place the tube between the 3 rollers and apply pressure to the pipe as you pull it through it will force it with constant pressure. The idea being that you set it to the natural bend of the part where it will return to its straight position. if it is bent more than that it will be bent back into shape if its straight it wont be deformed. from the test Ive done this is quite hard to get to.

If you want to see more and how I create prints and 3D designs like this check out my YouTube channel.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSHUc93NXGwBacoIDDqPU2w

Bill of materials

You will need 3x M8 bolts and nuts with washers.
You will need 3x of either 608z or 688x bearings
an M6 bolt around 90mm long with a nut to adjust.
For added strength you can add 2x 8mm shafts (75mm) as bearings to support the block but I haven't had to add it.

title: Star Wars EpVII Stormtrooper Helmet Keyring

description.text:
Using Geffro's fantastic design of the helmet and mount , I have remodeled the concept as a keyring. All creativity credit for my inspiration goes to Geoffro. Probably George Lucas as well.

His original is here
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:579146

All original idealistic content owned by Lucasfilm, Disney, blah blah blah

The keyring itself is quite small (27mm tall including loop), so to keep the detail, print no bigger than 0.1 layer height. I use 0.8mm shell, top and bottom as standard and used 15% infill. Took about 35 mins on UMO and UM2.
You will need support for the bottom as it is not perfectly flat (See pic).

Final print will be in white and will use a very small brush and steady hand to apply the black detail.

title: Carousel with mirrors
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple but effective carousel with mirrors.
We used it as an element of one of our projects, but you can use it to bring some light and colour to your parties at home :).
Designed to fit a MERCURY MOTOR SM-42BYG011-25.
The mirrors were cut at the size we needed (W: 9 mm, H:5 mm, L:43 mm).
The big screw is M6 and about 50 mm Long. The smaller screws are M3; and the length is not critical, but I used 12 mm long ones. The size of the carousel is 46 mm tall by 40 mm Diameter.

Put together the to halves of the carousel (You won't need to glue them) and then just put a washer, a nut and the M6 screw trough them to keep them together. Then place the cap that will connect the carousel to the motor. Finally put the mirrors and fix them with a bit of glue if you think they are loose.

title: Lab Gel Boat and Comb
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For those Biohackers and frugal lab-workers out there, here's a model of a Gel Boat and a comb for moulding wells and performing Gel Electrophoresis!
Given the huge price associated with commercially available gel boats, I hope this will find a few good homes where it'll be put to good use.
For those unfamiliar with Lab Gels, this rig is used to create jelly-like blocks of agar/agarose gel with special wells moulded in; into these wells, one injects DNA or Protein. When an electric current is applied through the Gel Longitudinally, the DNA (or charged protein) is dragged through the well in order of size, smallest fragment first. This allows separation of DNA based on size, which is a pretty essential lab technique for Biohackers.

This Gel Boat set is available for purchase on Shapeways at:

http://www.shapeways.com/shops/labsfromfabs


I intend to continue releasing my stuff to the public domain, but will also stock it in this shop for those without printers.


Note: I also resized the .stl files, according to Shapeways the boat should now be 95mm long.


Because I have no Makerbot yet, this model is in no way tested, and is probably completely the wrong size. I would love to see it printed by someone, and if resizing was required please give me copies of the resized object to replace these ones! The Gel Rig I use in the lab has a boat 10cm x 8cm, which should just fit in the Makerbot. I didn't size this one very carefully, sorry. If you want to try out extracting your own DNA and visualising it on a Gel using only available-at-home stuff, check out this article:
http://www.scq.ubc.ca/the-macgyver-project-genomic-dna-extraction-and-gel-electrophoresis-experiments-using-everyday-materials/

author: cathalgarvey

title: Filament joiner for multicoloured printed 3D objects

description.text: This is a simple temperature controlled heating block for joining plastic filament together in sections so you can print nice looking multicoloured objects like this - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9777 And this - http://www.thingiverse.com/derivative:10790 And this - http://www.thingiverse.com/derivative:10831 And this - http://www.thingiverse.com/derivative:10830

You may find more information on my Blog here - http://richrap.blogspot.com/2011_06_01_archive.html This is the basic Idea for making one -
People seem to do this in a number of different ways -
1) - Start the print with one colour filament, pause the print and reverse out the filament and load a new colour, continue the print.
2) - Join lengths of different coloured filament together and print them in one go (using hot-air guns or flames).
3) - Use multiple extruders with different coloured filament, produce some complicated Gcode to control them.
I tried joining with a flame (lighter) this is not a good idea, it does not work well and it's easy to snap the join after cooling, it also can char the filament, not something you want to feed into your extruder.
I then tried a flat heated block of Aluminium, melt both ends and join, roll them on the block, this works but can make a mess and it's a little fiddly.
And after a quick try of a hot-air gun (don't bother it's not easy at all) I decided to try and make a temperature controlled filament joiner -
I decided to make a Aluminium block with a heated channel so I can join and rotate the filament, this works really well and it only takes 5 seconds to join pre-cut lengths together. 1) - Cut an Aluminium block, drill a hole for the resistor (6.8Ohms) and then slice it so you have 'joining channels' 2) - Bond in the resistor (fire cement) and then insulate the bottom of the block with something that is not going to catch fire, PEEK, PTFE, silicon etc. 3) - Wire it up just like you would with a 3D printer hot-end and add a thermistor (I also added an LED to tell me when it's on)
Mount it to a block of wood or something you can clamp down. 4) - You can use your RAMPS electronics setup and a host program to control the temperature as it's the same as your hot-end. (if you have a resistor hot-end that is) I found a good temperature was about 160 Degrees C(For PLA, For ABS it's going to need to be hotter), this gives you time to heat and rotate the filament and also joins it really well. 5) - So if you hold a piece of filament in each hand and melt both ends on the side of the Alu block, then sith the into the grove and push together then give them a quick rotate you should have a joined filament (after a little practice). Improvements and changes to think about if you decide to build one - 1) - Have a shorter heating zone, just ~4mm for each side, this would help keep the filament more rigid when you twist it to remove the join.
2) - Have a bigger flat area that you can quickly melt both the filament ends, I'm using the side of the block to do this, but a bit more area would be good.
3) - Have a cold block or wet sponge to rapidly cool the joined filament in place or a foot pedel (you need both hands to hold the two filaments) controlled fan so you can blast cool it.
*- Maybe make the heating block clamp together in two halves like an electric plumbing pipe joiner - (See picture and if anyone makes one, let me know how well it works). If you had a foot-pedal controlled one of these for filament joining it may make the job even easier. Make one, you can print all sorts of cool looking things and lots of colours will just make them look even better. Please post improvements, ideas or your results.

comments.text:

author: Bl0K3

description.text:
This is a pegboard mounted filament spool holder.

I made the bracket 4x3 (pegs) for structural integrity, and I added extra sets of mounting holes so that you can double or tripple up arms on each bracket, or use them for accessories like the loc line ball mounts that can be used to mount cameras, lights, filament guide, helping hands, etc...

I highly recommend printing with ABS, as pla is much more brittle, and you risk the pegs snapping off with PLA. Definitely make sure your layer adhesion is calibrated well.

This setup can either just use an 8mm rod, or you can add 608 bearings to make it spin with less resistance.

This pegboard spool mount setup interfaces with the accessories from Thinkyhead's spool holder setup: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:78641

You can download the little 608 bearing adapter, and spool adapter's there from the link above. You might have to remove a little material from the inside of the little rod/bearing adapter, but you want it to be a snug fit.

I used m3x16mm screws, and m3 nuts and washers to mount the arms to the pegboard bracket.

I used an m3x40mm and an m3x25mm screw, and m3 nuts and washers to mount the horizontal and angled arms together.

You can see the orientation that I printed everything in the attached pictures. Basically just lay everything flat and print without support. You will probably have to clean up the little bent pegs with a small file and/or a hobby knife. I only attached the right side horizontal arm, but you can just flip it along the appropriate axis in your slicer to print the left side horizontal arm.

Be very careful inserting the bracket into the pegboard. If you insert the bent pegs unevenly and try to rotate down, the torque can snap them off. If you need them to be more rigid, you can print the bracket vertically, with support, so that the layers are parallel with the pegs. This will obviously require more post-print cleanup.

UPDATE 8/28/2015: I designed some little ball mounts that mount to the extra holes in the pegboard bracket. I use the loc lines for all kinds of stuff, i.e. helping hands, light holders, and in this case, a filament guide.

The loc lines can be purchased here for under $7 for 6: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008O14864?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage

I simply bend the nozzle on the loc line till it pops off, and i do the same with the little threaded adapter at the other end. I take the nozzle and send a m3x16mm socket cap screw through it, and screw it into the filament guide. I then snap the other end to the ball mount, and then screw the ball mount to the pegboard bracket.

UPDATE 8/29/2015 - I added slightly adjusted spindle adapters for 30mm id spools, and 50mm id spools. I also added slightly adjusted rod/bearing adapters. The originals fit tight and required removal of material. The new ones fit like a glove, at least on my printer.

My younger cousin recently found an affinity for the Eiffel Tower and wanted me to send her a 3D printed copy. I didn't want to ship a large and fragile 3D model, so I decided to make a flat pack version inspired by my flat pack foxes. This allowed me to send a couple to her with no more then a postage stamp and a small padded envelope.

Included here are two versions; HD and SD. The HD version has all the fine ironwork within the tower and requires either a smaller nozzle, or a scale-up to resolve all the detail. The SD version is a simple silhouette and can be printed quickly and easily.

1. Print without support or rafts if possible.
  2. Use slots so slide pieces together.
  3. Print another
  4. Go to #2

author: spindle_dev

description.text:
It took me a while but I finally got my water feature working - an excellent design by gzumwalt.
This remix is not a million miles away from the original design - just two of the parts changed slightly.
My version of the motor splash cover encloses the motor and is long enough to reach the bottom of the motor mount.
I closed the open reed switch shaft at the top of the cup in order to prevent the ingress of water.

All of the non-printed parts were sourced in the UK. The magnets came via EBay, the motor is the "small motor" from Maplin (part number YG13P) and the reed switch, also from Maplin, is their "min reed switch" part number N30AN.
To form the latch, I cut a strip from an empty baked bean tin, folded it in half and then in half again, squashing the resulting strip tightly together with pliers - this was a good tight fit in the latch strip slot. One of my early failures came during some post assembly adjusting of the latch strip. I ended up snapping it off after bending it over as described by gzumwalt. I now have it standing proud by a couple of mm, enabling me to adjust its position by gripping it with pliers. As I don't have a bench power supply, I tried a 3V mains charger to power the motor but ran into trouble after around 45 minutes of operation - the reed switch started to stick. This was possibly either because of some sort of welding effect or perhaps down to the reed contacts magnetising. (The current draw is quite high - something like at least 800mA at 3V). At one point the motor kept running even when the magnets AND the latch strip were totally removed, only stopping after a sharp tap on the reed switch housing shaft!. I am now using a single D cell to run the motor as shown in the photograph but being battery operated, I am not sure how long it will last. I am going to try putting a 2R7 3W resistor in series with the motor which should drop enough of the 3V from my mains adapter and reduce the motor current to something like the same as when using a single 1.5V battery. The 1.5V supply gives enough flow to fill the cup faster than water leaks out at the bottom.

description.text: with 8mm tube easy to assemble

Parts for the KD6JDJ Double Cross Antenna (See http://www.poes-weather.com/download/jm-dca/MARTES_Double_Cross_Antenna.pdf for analysis and plans)

Made to fit imperial PVC sizes and thick wire, but you might need to modify the parts so I included the solidworks files.

73s
KE7PHI

I printed using my robust ABS profile:
0.2mm layer heights
1.2mm perimeters
1mm floor and cielings
35% rectangular infill

I included two versions of the mast mounts, one has holes in the arms and one doesn't (you can glue, or drill your own). I printed the no-holes without supports because the version with the holes will probably need supports to print well.

The arms need to be tilted 30 degrees from vertical, so I included arrows that should line up with the mast (or another vertical reference) for easy eyeballing. Also, the tips of the side arrows match the center of the dipoles, so measuring the exact center to dipole spacing is a lot easier. you can add a little sharpee dot like I did if you like for a better visual aid when out in the field.

I hope this works for you!

73s
KE7PHI

title: HP Microserver - 5.25" face plate replacement panel

description.text:
I managed to misplace the 5.25" bay face plate from my HP microserver and wanted to replace it with something.

I've included 3 models (in order of least to most airflow)
1: Blank face plate
2: Alternate stepped slotted vents
3: Hex perforated vents (see v2 for fixed up tabs/clips)

I've printed the slotted faceplate on my Prusa i3 printer successfully with 100% infill.

The blank face version was an iteration between the alternate stepped slots and the hex perforations - I needed more airlflow :)

To make the hex perforated print easier on cleanup, I've used slic3r and disabled the 'brim' and enabled the skirt with 0mm distance with 4 loops. Hopefully this means only an effective brim on the outside.

Update: I've uploaded a v2 of the Hex perforated version. The original version for some reason didn't print the tabs/clips on the sides. Slic3r renders this version correctly, and I'll print it out later today to confirm all is well. Real photos will follow :)

I designed this USB pen case in function of a Kingston flash drive size and I printed it with my Prusa i3. I sliced it with 25% infill density and 0.1 mm layer height.

This handle would probably not be relevant to anyone else but I wanted to show it in any case. Who knows, someone might still find it useful so I included the Solidworks 2010 design files too.
The two end seats on our lounge suite are recliners and the release handle on the one broke about a year ago. Even though I've had my RapMan a few months now it only hit me about a week ago to design a new release handle for it.
I split it into two pieces to make it printable without support.

• Print one of each.
  • Insert the M4 nut into the square opening close to the flat top of the handle "arm".
  • Place the "top" on the "arm" as per the assembled image and insert and tighten the M4 screw.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k4DiPMDZv9c
Extrusora para fabricar filamento, inspirada en la extrusora Lymann.
La cabeza extrusora contiene un total de 9 cartuchos ceramicos de 40w, divididos en 3 grupos de 4+4+1 cada grupo de heaters estan controlados de forma independiente por una placa Ultimaker 1.5.7, los 3 grupos están configurados cada uno como extruder1 extruder2 y heatbed, El motor que mueve el husillo es de velocidad fija de 220v, el control del motor de arrastre del filamento y del carrete de recojida del filamento son circuitos independientes con i.c. 555 que gobiernan los A4988.

Los piñones son de 16 18 y 20 dientes modulo 1.5
La corona con eje exagonal de 9mm que encaja en la broca para madera que hace de husillo.

This mount adapts a KitchenAid grinder for use on a Ronco Pasta Machine base.

I wanted to make sausage, so was searching for a meat grinder, and found a brand new KitchenAid grinder (with the sausage attachment!!) at a thrift store, for $10.

But I don't own the KitchenAid mixer. But I did have faith, and bought it anyway...

Eventually, I made this mounting bracket to fit a previous thrift store find... A Ronco Pasta Maker. They are pretty common at thrift stores these days. Many people bought them, but didn't use them very much. I found one in as-new condition, with ALL the accessories, for about $8. Over time, I bought three, mostly for the powerful base motors, and for spare parts, and one is now devoted to this grinder attachment.

The pasta maker will make real good fresh pasta if you know what you are doing. It can mix and then extrude a rather large batch of thick dough, so I felt the base motor would be plenty powerful enough to grind meat too. The Pasta machine power take-off rotates at 120 RPM (2 rotations per second) and that seemed about right.

The pasta machine comes apart easily with just four screws. The front shell-half to which bolts are mounted is nothing but a thick plastic shell. Once hole positions are marked, it's a simple matter to drill the 4 holes.

The KitchenAid grinder attachment gets very high customer ratings as a good little grinder, and it works great for me. It's a good design, it grinds meat real well, and is easy to clean.

There is very little stress on the massive printed mount bracket so it's plenty strong enough. Surprising to me was that the printed drive shaft is also strong enough. You'd think (at least I did) that the torque of the motor would probably snap this shaft, and while I tried to reinforce it in the design stage, I still predicted needing to make one out of a stronger material. But after several hours of use it shows no signs of stress.
Anyway, if I accidentally drop a bone in the grinder, that shaft will no doubt break first, so it's sort of like a safety fuse..

Note that the base plate on the mount is slightly tapered to match the slope on the face of the pasta maker. So, it is not flat on your build plate. One edge is raised up. I only mention this because some people have complained when files are not flat on the bottom. Don't ask me why they don't like it....

The mount took about 4 hours and used 150 grams of ABS on an Afinia, with 0.35mm layers.
Files are SAE. On the million to one chance someone else will actually do this, and needs metric, scale the stl files up by a factor of 25.4.

Converts rotation into reciprocating (linear back & forth) motion.
Functioning parameterized design, so you can make it as big as you want.
I designed this as a motion study, and to see how well this would work on a 3d-printer.  It works surprisingly well.
It's currently designed to be hand-operated, but easily modifiable to be motor-driven.  Motor-driving it is on my short-list.
In the hand-driven configuration, it needs to be held together by hand as you turn it to get the correct motion.  
I would be very happy to see your application for this!
The case could use some modifications (e.g. attachment points) depending on your application.
I recommend a Frequency 3, Radius 1 inch, Height 1 inch as a working starting point.
Anything below Frequency 3 will bind.  I've tried 1, 2, and 3.  If you modelled in some support tracks for Freq 1 or 2, it could work.
Anything below about a 1:1 ratio (radius to amplitude) will bind at frequency 3 (I've gotten a 1:2 at frequency 1 almost working, adding extra support track may fix this if you want to try something small with longer travel)

Edit mechanism.scad to set paramters: amplitude: size of linear motion peak-to-peak
frequency: how many peaks per rotation
bearing_radius: how big are your balls
inner_radius: how wide should the moving part be
outer_radius: how thick should the outer case be
lip_radius: how wide should the 'handle' be
lip_height: how tall should the 'handle' be
shaft_radius: save material or make a drive-shaft slip-fit optionally adjust these on your next print:
ring_slip: slip between outer and inner rings
bearing_slip: slip around balls Export the stl files. I do this by commenting out (//) all but the part I am exporting from the --- CSG --- block at the bottom of the file. Expect the sine_toroid_race to take a very long time to render: hopefully someone adds better intersection handling or lofting to the next version of scad. Print:
1x outer case
1x torus race
1x sine torus race
Nx slide (where N=Frequency) Assemble:
1) insert Torus Race into Outer Case, leaving the race exposed.
2) insert a Slide into every track in the Outer Case, overlap the ball hole with the Torus Race, and insert a ball into each of the slides. It's easy with 3 or fewer slides. If your frequency is >3, you may need extra fingers.
3) push the Torus Race into the Outer Case so the 2nd hole on the slide is just sticking out.
4) insert the Sine race and line the race up with the holes on the slides. Carefully insert the balls through the holes into the race.
5) push the sine race all the way in.
6) Grab the outer case in one hand, and the lip in the other. Rotate the sine race via the lip while keeping the pieces pressed together.

cable retainer
Mount a longboard or skateboard on your wall horizontally with the graphics facing outward. The board is easily removed by pivoting the top hook and sliding the board up and out.

Print three identical hooks. Two will be used to hold the board from the bottom and the third will be able to pivot, locking in or releasing the board from the top.
At the least, the two bottom hooks should be screwed into studs, or should use the proper drywall mounts, toggles, etc. to support the weight of the board.
The top hook should be screwed into the wall more loosely, optionally with a washer between it and the wall so that it can rotate to insert and release the board.

description.text: This was a request by my grandfather to make a stake to hold his drip watering tubes for his garden. They hold a 1/4 inch outer diameter tube on the top and are a little over six inches long. They should probably be made in abs or other high temperature plastic if you will be putting them outside in direct sunlight or high temperatures. I made my originals in PLA and they start to warp in 100*F days.
I made my originals in PLA with 0.3 mm layers, inverted on the build plate (see picture). Should probably make them in ABS to withstand heat better.

comments.text: Just an aside, I remixed it to allow the tube to be going vertical. thanks for the original design. Printed mine with PETG and with about 35% triangle infill.

v2.0!

  • Outside of tokens less jagged
  • Repair joints on hollow numbers like '6'
  • Increase size of the line underneath ambiguous numbers
  • Add support for 'dual extrusion' (see instructions)

Kelly Pool is a game variation that allows more than 2 people to a pool table. When I wanted to play this, I used to just cut up some pieces of paper and write numbers on them. These tokens are so much nicer!

Gameplay involves players drawing numbers at random, which assigns to them the correspondingly numbered pool ball (kept secret from their opponents).

Generally the players must pocket their assigned balls (hitting the lowest numbered ball first each turn) to win the game. You can play however you wish though; I also like to play reversed - you avoid hitting your numbers. Each time a number is potted the person it belongs to will place their token onto the side of the table. The player who has the token for the the last ball on the table wins!

It is a simple game, and a great way to include more players than the standard two.

More about Kelly Pool (including proper rules):
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kelly_pool

SINGLE COLOUR
My settings: 0.2 Layer Height, 100% Infill, 0.4mm Nozzle
For producing these in a single colour, I would recommend use of the 1-15 file. If you're not confident they will all stay stuck down until its done, then print only a few at once using the individual files. For single colour extrusion, always use the "Kelly-Pool-Token_Supported" Files because these have support inside for open numbers like '6' and '0'.

DUAL COLOUR
My settings: 0.2 Layer Height, 100% Infill, 0.4mm Nozzle, Purge Wall (Makerbot Desktop)
Open your printing application, Import a single numbered token, import single solid blank token (line up perfectly with the numbered one), then change colour of the 2 pieces as desired. Select both pieces and move together to location on build platform. Repeat this for as many pieces as you think your printer can handle at once without stuffing up! I would recommend doing only a few tokens at a time when working with dual extrusion.

EXTRA INFO
I decided not to include a single 1-15 file for dual extrusion because it's better if you customize the setup based on your printer. For example - I found that for me the best way to print in dual is to do only 4 tokens at a time and to arrange them close together along the Y axis (front to back). My hot ends are side by side along the X axis, so printing like this prevents the leaky nozzles from ever crossing over and messily wiping unwanted pieces of colour on the unfinished tokens.

I included unsupported tokens for use with dual extrusion prints, as the hollow numbers will be supported by the second colour. You can also use the supported number design for dual extrusion though. This is still my preference.

comments.text: If you print these at 0.9827 scale on the X and Y axis they should be the same size as tokens for GF9(Gale Force 9) Tanks! game

Based on SnakeEyes (Now Playing - Vinyl LP Wall Display Mounts)

I wanted to display my vinyl without screwing holes into my walls. During one short trip to my local DollarTree, I came across some poster tack, figured I'd try it. (so far it has been 12 hours at the time of this upload with this tack holding up my eagles vinyl)

title: Smart LCD mount for Kossel 2020 with USB connector

description.text:
I modified Rambozo's LCD mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:846900) to include enough room for a USB extension cable. This way the SD card is on the left of the LCD mount, and USB connector is on the right in case I want to directly hook up a laptop.

Snaps onto the LCD and into the 2020 frame. If it's difficult to get onto the smart LCD, apply a little heat (e.g. a flame, briefly) to the "ears" to soften them slightly so they can be bent a bit.

This fits USB extension cable from StarTech model USBPNLBFBM1 (http://www.startech.com/Cables/USB-2.0/Internal-and-Panel-Mount/1-ft-Panel-Mount-USB-Cable-B-to-B-Female-to-Male~USBPNLBFBM1)

author: evandepol

title: Gopro Fork Mount for Dirt Bike Fork

description.text:
Gopro mount for the fork of a dirt bike. Made specifically to fit a wr450f, but would likely fit almost any bike with the same fork diameter (59.5 mm or so). Use m5 bolts to clamp it down, and the m5 bolt that comes with the gopro to mount the camera itself. I have had good luck printing at .2 layer height with no support material made with abs, but your printer settings may vary. Hope it's useful to someone else too!

-Included is the solidworks file in case anyone needs to edit the sketch, or change the diameter for a different fork size.

description.text:
This coffee grinder have a dosing system built-in. We won't using this carousel and it was easier to have a dose free system, so that we can fill a mason jar before going to the coffee machine. This part can replace the dosing carousel for just a simple funnel.

There's probably not a lot of people having the same problem with the same specific coffee grinder, but at least it can maybe give some ideas. Nothing fancy ;)

If you have the same machine you can remove everything with an allen key and a phillips screwdriver. You also can re-use the same screws to put this part unto your machine.

The square one is the one that worked the best for us.

title: Print Your Ride!!! (derived from Print your Run!!!)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I printed a few mountain and road bike rides using the original pde from SNRK (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:276911) and thought they were great. As a few of my friends responded to my offers to print their rides, I got a few that wouldn't work with the original. Using comments from SNRK on his original post, I was able to up the resolution. Additionally, I believe I've found and corrected a bug that caused 2:1 x-axis compression. Edit line #45 of the PDE to match your GPX filename and print away!

An additional pde with brush size inceased to 2.0 has been added. If you find the higher resolution prints to be too insubstantial, try it.

14 December 2015 Added similarly modded version of floating track.

22 March 2016 It is no longer necessary to edit line #45 to include your filename, if you name your file "input.gpx".

22 March 2016 Added executables for Windows with 64-bit Java. No library downloads or Processing application work required.

  1. Unzip the archive
  2. Place "input.gpx" in the same folder as the executable.
  3. Run the executable.
  4. Press "s" on the keyboard.
  5. Open and slice "path.stl" with your favorite printing software.

28 December 2017 I added a sample GPX for testing that you have Java and the application installed correctly. Currently, the exe version of this script is not compatible with Bitdefender (unless you follow the instructions here: https://www.bitdefender.com/consumer/support/answer/2393/).

If Linux or Win32 executables are needed, I can generate them. The amount of effort required means that I won't unless someone specifically requests them.

Processing:
https://processing.org/download/?processing

GPX libs:
https://github.com/RandomEtc/processing-gpx

toxiclibs:
https://bitbucket.org/postspectacular/toxiclibs/downloads

comments.author: kimskibum

comments.text: No silly questions on this one, as the whole process is a little esoteric.  You download one of the 2 PDE files from the "Thing Files" tab.  Place your GPX in the same directory as the PDE.  Using a text-editor, edit line #45  of the downloaded PDE to include the name of your GPX file, inside the quotes. Open the PDE in Processing (double-click usually works). Click the "Play" button in Processing.. Select the model preview window and hit the 's' key on your keyboard to save the printable STL.

author: blackdice

description.text:
This is a conceptual placeholder for an adjustable polarizer mount for a home-made ellipsometer apparatus I am working on right now. It is intended for rotate-able polarizers that normally go into optical microscopes. I did not put threads into the main aperture since I think (when I finally get my printer) I will be able to press fit the metal rim into the softer ABS plastic material. I will update as I learn the real-world lessons on this. Update: I added two manually rotatate-able inserts. Print at your own risk since this is still just a proof-of-concept design. I will not know if any of this will work until I get my new printer and do some measurements with a pair of calipers. Update 06/11/13
I had to modify the polarizer mount radius to fit the microscope-based polarizers I purchased (version 3). It appears that the bolt holes (and set-screw holes for the laser module) fit well for standard M3-0.5 socket cap screws. Curently working of AOI arm design and prints. I will update to a separate project ("Printable Ellipsometer") with component sourcing, calibration, etc., soon. Work is progressing.

author: serpini

description.text:
Art framing can be ridiculously expensive. However, a good framing job makes the artwork look much, much better. With that in mind, I want to try printing a frame for a (art) print I bought. 
This is basic example of an art frame that can be printed on a 3d printer. Many different profiles can be made to suit many different types of art, but I just mocked up a quick one as an example of the basic principle.

I've only supplied the Sketchup files for now, since you might want a different profile, or want to adjust the side lengths to fit your artwork or printer build area. I really just wanted to post this to get some feedback and refine the idea, but you should be able to print this and get a small frame as long as you have a .stl export plugin.
Print out 4 (or more) side pieces [dark blue], and 4 of each type of corner piece (left hand and right hand). You'll also need 4 of the corner joining pieces [cyan].
Once printed, just assemble it all together as shown in the picture to the left. The pieces have to be glued or screwed together, however I think the best solution will be just melting pieces together with a hot knife or soldering iron.
Since this is just a proof of concept (for now) there is no allowance made for hanging hardware or joining multiple side pieces together or holding the artwork in place. 
Another concern is the surface will be a 3d printed surface, so not smooth. I think that "real" wood frames are covered with a putty or clay to even out the wood grain, and to give a smooth surface for gold leaf to adhere to. I think the same technique could be used here, possibly with better results, since the plastic won't expand and contract with humidity changes. the putty would also cover any gaps where the separate pieces are joined together.

title: Wanhao Duplicator y-axis NEMA motor mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I had a slight problem with my y-axis motor being 'pulled in' and was causing belt wear and unwanted lines in my prints. You will have to drill 4 holes in the frame of the i3, so do this at your own risk.

Edit 8/29/15 - Working on the y-idler assembly now, should be up this evening! See it here! (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:992552)

Tips and tricks:
1) Print this in the same fashion that you'd put it on the printer, the 4 motor mounting holes that are 'ears' should be the top.
2) I used ABS as it does have to bend a tad to get the motor in there.
3) I had the best luck taking the set screw and pulley off.
4) Some motors have a different dimensions so you might have to put a washer in between the motor and mount
5) One more thing, unscrewing the back bolts off the NEMA motor and using this, you will have to get 2 or 4 M3x30/35mm bolts.

comments.text: Do you have any suggestions in lining up the new mount to be able to drill the holes?  Since we have to drill four new holes I wanted to try and get it as straight as possible.
comments.author: wolf9545

comments.text: I used my eyeballs and guessed. You don't have to be perfect, drill a little bigger than the screw and you can use the NEMA stepper shaft and pulley to make up a good ~4mm of "give"
comments.author: wolf9545

comments.text: This mount is cool. Thanks for posting. I'll probably make one eventually, but to align my y-motor to the frame, I swapped one of the M3 bolts holding the motor bracket to the frame with an 8mm long one to push the motor in a bit - so a similar solution to the comment about just adding a spacer. Now its almost perfectly aligned. 30 second fix YMMV.
comments.author: DockGuy

comments.text: Thanks for the input and nice words! Hope it works for ya :)
comments.author: DockGuy

comments.text: Great work,
comments.author: GRay_111111

comments.text:
I'm just printing this, to pair up with "Thing 1532408" (which seems a sympathetic design for pairing), plus I'm designing a belt tensioner / bed attachment (using an Allen bolt to fine adjust tension) so hopefully this will yield a nice Y-transmission.
IMHO, adding a base is irrelevant for "binding together" as the NEMA motor itself becomes integral to the rigidity (assuming spacers / washers are nice and snug.) The base would add a level of adhesion of the motor assembly / "cheeks" to the plate / frame area but time will tell if that's an issue! Agree with tjlqk3 that such a base plate might cause more little issues than it solves.
comments.author: GRay_111111

comments.text: If I bound them together, it might cause it to be much harder to place the motor in there. If you are thinking something different feel free to email me a drawing and I'll design up a piece. [email protected]
comments.author: GRay_111111

comments.text: Corrected scaling.
comments.author: tjlqk3

comments.text: Wouldn't printing a spacer do pretty much the same thing?
comments.author: vgf89

comments.text: Spacer? Instead of using a washer?
comments.author: vgf89

comments.text: No, I meant something more stupid: instead of printing a whole new bracket (which I probably will do anyways), just shove a spacer between the back frame and the motor to make it sit straight instead of at a slight angle.
comments.author: tjlqk3

comments.text: Ha, funny you mention that. I tried that but it kept moving around on me as well with the vibrations etc. It wasn't too hard to install, just have to be careful around the bundle of wires. I had to Dremel the corner out of the wire hole to get the 4th bolt in. But its working very well on my printer right now!
comments.author: vgf89

Due to my Lawnmower handle breaking and pulling the cord by hand I damaged the first joint on my finger tip it was healing kind of pointing inwards a bit. So...I made this slightly curved piece ( curve pushing the finger tip upwards slightly) from scratch to slide on my index finger while keeping the tip free to type etc yet being tight enough to keep the tip straight so it heals properly. Got tired of reapplying tape on a regular splint every time I washed hands or showered. This is NO FUSS. Sized to my index finger but one can easily size in their slicer program if it doesn't fit. You can print a small section and stop to see if it fits then size in your slicer program, then print a full one.
Printed at .2mm layer height zero infill in about 8-9 minutes on my Rostock Max Hope someone finds this useful!

comments.text: Next time you should print a new mower handle rather than pulling the cord by hand.  :)
comments.author: lowlight

comments.text: haha!  Yes I actually did! There is one awesome one here I printed it within 1 hour of finding it, have to do the grass again tomorrow so its all ready to go. Wish I checked here BEFORE cutting the grass last week.

comments.text: OH I'm sorry to hear that! I was lucky to only hurt one finger, hope it healed up well

title: Ryobi Battery Sleeve with Switches for Model Rocketry

description.text: A handle or sleeve with switches to connect to an 18V Ryobi for launching model rockets

Print the parts (one of each except 2X glue rings). Glue the sleeve to the clip plate and reinforce by gluing one ring at the bottom. Use some 1/4" flat brass bars (from local hardware store) to create contacts on the terminal clip. I soldered mine and then attached some wire to connect to the switch. Glue the completed terminal clip to the top of the sleeve and reinforce near the upper area with a second glue ring. This will keep force on the terminal contacts to maintain your connection to the Ryobi battery. Glue one side of the switch shell to the assembly and wire in your switch. I used a Cut-off Machine DPST NO AC 220V 380V 10A Trigger Switch FA2-10/2B from Amazon. Depending on your application, you may want a safety switch on the top. I wired a simple toggle switch from Radio Shack to the top as a safety and ran the wires out of the hole in the front to a power connector. Create a length of cable with alligator clips and enjoy launching your model rockets.

comments.text: I found many 18volt drills have similar sized bent metal clips to contact the batteries. If you have a local re-purposing/junk yard, you can get dead drills for practically nothing. Unscrew and you have clips and some wire, usually get a working motor too.
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text:
well, since this project require drill trigger assembly, why not spend $1 more and get drill trigger assembly WITH battery contact?
you can get that for $6 on ebay from some Chinese seller.
comments.author: MichaelAtOz
